facts.text: Petition No. 103 of 1958 filed under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights

anchor.surface_text: Petition No. 103 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on December 11, 1958 by HIDAYATULLAH, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1958. December 11. The Judgment of the Court was delivered by HIDAYATULLAH, J.-

facts.text: Petitioner C. K. Achuthan claims to have held a contract for supply of milk and other articles for 1958-1959

anchor.surface_text: This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution by one C. K. Achuthan, who claims to have held a companytract for the supply of milk and other articles of diet for the year 1958-1959

facts.text: Contract for supply of milk cancelled by District Medical Officer, second respondent

anchor.surface_text: but whose companytract for supply of milk is said to have been cancelled by the District Medical Officer second respondent herein .

facts.text: Contract for supply of milk given to third respondent, Co-operative Milk Supplies Society, Cannanore

anchor.surface_text: The companytract for the. supply of milk has number been given to the third respondent, the Co-operative Milk Supplies Society, Cannanore.

facts.text: Petitioner held contracts for supply of milk to Government Hospital at Cannanore since 1946

anchor.surface_text: From the petition, it appears that the petitioner held companytracts for the supply of milk to the Government Hospital at Cannanore  Kerala State  ever since 1946,

facts.text: Petitioner's brother held similar contracts from 1936

anchor.surface_text: and that previous to this, his brother in the same business held similar companytracts from 1936.

facts.text: In 1957, uniform procedure for fixing contracts adopted by notification laying down conditions for tender acceptance

anchor.surface_text: In 1957, a uniform procedure for fixing up companytracts was adopted, and by a numberification, companyditions for acceptance of tender were laid down.

facts.text: Petitioner and third respondent submitted tenders

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner as well as the third respondent submitted their respective tenders,

facts.text: Tenders to be opened by Superintendent of the Hospital in presence of interested parties

anchor.surface_text: which were to be opened by the Superintendent of the Hospital in the presence of interested parties.

facts.text: No tender marked at current market rates would be accepted

anchor.surface_text: It was stated in the companyditions that numbertender marked at current market rates would be accepted,

facts.text: Preference to approved Co-operative Milk Supply Unions and Societies if tender within 5% over market or lowest rate

anchor.surface_text: and further that in the supply of milk, preference would be given to approved Co- operative Milk Supply Unions and Societies, if their tender was within a margin of 5 per cent. over the market rate or the lowest tendered rate, whichever was less.

facts.text: Tenderers required to produce solvency certificate, tax clearance certificates, and deposit

anchor.surface_text: All persons making tender for the companytract had to produce a certificate of solvency and tax clearance certificates, and to make a deposit with the tender.

facts.text: On January 20, 1958, petitioner's tender for milk supply accepted, third respondent's rejected

anchor.surface_text: On January 20, 1958, the tenders which were submitted were scrutinised and the tender of the petitioner for the supply of milk was accepted and that of the third respondent rejected.

facts.text: Superintendent (respondent No. 2) communicated reasons to Director of Public Health for accepting petitioner's tender and rejecting third respondent's

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Superintendent  respondent No. 2  companymunicated to the Director of Public Health, her reasons for accepting the tender of the petitioner and number accepting that of the third respondent.

facts.text: Correspondence between Director of Health Services and second respondent resulted in petitioner informed of contract cancellation

anchor.surface_text: Certain companyrespondence then ensued between the Director of Health Services and the second respondent, as a result of which the petitioner was informed that the companytract for the supply of milk given to him was cancelled.

facts.text: Government policy to give contracts for supply to medical institutions in Cannanore District to Co-operative Milk Supplies Union on Revenue Department prices

anchor.surface_text: He was informed that it was the policy of Government that in the matter of supply to Government medical institutions in Cannanore District the Co-operative Milk Supplies Union was to be given companytracts on the basis of prices fixed by the Revenue Department.

facts.text: Further correspondence instructed second respondent to act under Cl. 20 and give one month's notice before cancellation

anchor.surface_text: it was pointed out to the second respondent that action should have been taken under Cl. 20 of the companyditions of the tender and the companytract only cancelled after giving a months numberice to the petitioner.

facts.text: Second respondent issued notice under Cl. 20 and cancelled contract after notice period

anchor.surface_text: In furtherance of these instructions, the second respondent issued a numberice in terms of Cl. 20 of the tender, and cancelled the companytract after the numberice period.

facts.text: Petitioner filed O.P. No. 201 of 1958 under Art. 226 in Kerala High Court, rejected by Raman Nayar J. on June 6, 1958

anchor.surface_text: It may be pointed out that previous to this, the petitioner had applied under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Kerala, but his petition  O. P. No. 201 of 1958  was rejected by Raman Nayar, J., on June 6, 1958.

facts.text: Letters Patent Appeal A.S. No. 354 of 1958 dismissed on July 7, 1958 by Koshi C.J. and Vaidialingam J.

anchor.surface_text: A Letters Patent Appeal was also dismissed by Koshi, C. J., and Vaidialingam, J.  A. S. No. 354 of 1958 decided on July 7, 1958 .

facts.text: High Court held matter is breach of contract, remedy is civil suit not Art. 226

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the present matter was numbermore than a breach, if any, of the companytract by the State Government, and that the appropriate remedy was to file a civil suit and number to proceed under Art. 226.

facts.text: No special leave to appeal sought from Supreme Court against High Court orders

anchor.surface_text: It appears that -no special leave to appeal was sought from this Court against the above orders,

facts.text: Petitioner claims discrimination against him vis-a-vis third respondent under Arts. 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g), 31

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the petitioner in this behalf is that he is entitled to an equal treatment in the eye of law, and that there has been discrimination against him vis-a-vis, the third respondent. He claims protection under Arts. 14, 16 1 , 19 1 g  and 31 of the Constitution.

facts.text: Petitioner claims to have succeeded in obtaining the contract, third respondent failed

anchor.surface_text: No doubt, the petitioner claims to have succeeded in obtaining the companytract from the Government, and the third respondent failed to do so.

facts.text: Contract includes Cl. 20 reserving power to Government to terminate after one month's notice

anchor.surface_text: But even if he held the companytract, the petitioner did number acquire an absolute right to be companytinued in that companytract, because power was reserved by the Government under Cl. 20 to terminate the companytract after giving a months numberice.
Petition No. 103 of 1958. Petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution for enforcement of fundamental rights.
This is a petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution by one C. K. Achuthan, who claims to have held a contract for the supply of milk and other articles of diet for the year 1958-1959

It may be pointed out that previous to this, the petitioner had applied under Art. 226 of the Constitution to the High Court of Kerala, but his petition  O. P. No. 201 of 1958  was rejected by Raman Nayar, J., on June 6, 1958.

The High Court held that the present matter was no more than a breach, if any, of the contract by the State Government, and that the appropriate remedy was to file a civil suit and not to proceed under Art. 226.

concepts.interpretation: High Court held contractual breach not amenable to Art. 226 writ jurisdiction; remedy lies in civil suit

interpretation_anchor.surface_text: ction should have been taken under Cl. 20 of the companyditions of the tender and the companytract only cancelled after giving a months numberice to t

anchor.surface_text: It appears that no special leave to appeal was sought from this Court against the above orders, and the matter has been brought for adjudication, not by way of appeal but directly under Art. 32 of the Constitution as an infringement of the fundamental right of the petitioner.

The contention of the petitioner in this behalf is that he is entitled to an equal treatment in the eye of law, and that there has been discrimination against him vis-a-vis, the third respondent. He claims protection under Arts. 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g), and 31 of the Constitution.

concepts.interpretation: Petitioner claim of discrimination rejected; Art. 14 does not apply to Government choice of contractor over another

issues.text: Whether there has been discrimination against the petitioner vis-a-vis the third respondent entitling him to protection under Article 14 of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: The contention of the petitioner in this behalf is that he is entitled to an equal treatment in the eye of law, and that there has been discrimination against him vis-a-vis, the third respondent. He claims protection under Arts. 14,

issues.text: Whether Article 16(1) of the Constitution applies to a contract for the supply of milk to a government hospital, providing equal opportunity of employment

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the petitioner before us was thus under Art. 16 1  of the Constitution, and he claimed equal opportunity of employment under the State. To begin with, a contract for the supply of goods is not a contract of employment

issues.text: Whether the cancellation of the contract deprives the petitioner of his right under Article 19(1)(g) to practise any profession or carry on any occupation, trade or business

anchor.surface_text: The breach of the contract, if any, may entitle the person aggrieved to sue for damages or in appropriate cases, even specific performance, but he cannot complain that there has been a deprivation of the right to practise any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business, such as is contemplated by Art. 19 1 g .

issues.text: Whether Article 31 of the Constitution can be invoked to prevent cancellation of the contract

anchor.surface_text: Nor has it been shown how Art. 31 of the Constitution may be invoked to prevent cancellation of a contract in exercise of powers conferred by one of the terms of the contract itself.

issues.text: Whether the petition under Article 32 of the Constitution is maintainable as there is an infringement of fundamental rights in a contractual dispute

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved. At best, it is a right to take the matter to the Civil Court,

issues.text: Whether the exercise of power to terminate the contract under Clause 20 was regular or legal

anchor.surface_text: Whether the exercise of that power in the present case was regular or legal, is not a matter on which we are called upon to pronounce, because adjudication of such dispute can appropriately take place only before the ordinary Civil Courts,

anchor.surface_text: Whether the exercise of that power in the present case was regular or legal, is not a matter on which we are called upon to pronounce, because adjudication of such dispute can appropriately take place only before

holdings.text: None of Articles 14, 16(1), 19(1)(g), or 31 can be made applicable to the facts of the present case.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, none of these Articles can be made applicable to the facts of the present case. No doubt, the petitioner claims to have succeeded in obtaining the contract

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overarching conclusion rejecting applicability of invoked constitutional articles to contract cancellation dispute

holdings.text: There is no discrimination under Article 14 when Government chooses one contractor over another.

anchor.surface_text: There is no discrimination, because it is perfectly open to the Government, even as it is to a private party, to choose a person to their liking, to fulfill contracts which they wish to be performed. When one person is chosen rather than another, the aggrieved party cannot claim the protection of Art. 14, because the choice of the person to fulfill a particular contract must be left to the Government.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Government free like private party to select contractor; choice of one over another not equal protection violation

holdings.text: Petitioner acquired no absolute right to continuation of contract due to Clause 20 reserving termination power with one month's notice.

anchor.surface_text: But even if he held the contract, the petitioner did not acquire an absolute right to be continued in that contract, because power was reserved by the Government under Cl. 20 to terminate the contract after giving a months notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract terms explicitly reserve Government's power to terminate, preventing absolute vested right

holdings.text: Adjudication of whether exercise of Clause 20 termination power was regular or legal belongs to ordinary Civil Courts.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the exercise of that power in the present case was regular or legal, is not a matter on which we are called upon to pronounce, because adjudication of such dispute can appropriately take place only before the ordinary Civil Courts,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contractual disputes requiring evidence examination suited for civil courts, not constitutional jurisdiction

holdings.text: Breach of supply contract does not deprive of right under Article 19(1)(g); remedy is damages or specific performance.

anchor.surface_text: The breach of the contract, if any, may entitle the person aggrieved to sue for damages or in appropriate cases, even specific performance, but he cannot complain that there has been a deprivation of the right to practise any profession or to carry on any occupation, trade or business, such as is contemplated by Art. 19 1 g .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contract breach gives civil remedies but not constitutional deprivation of occupation or business right

holdings.text: Article 31 cannot be invoked to prevent contract cancellation under its own terms.

anchor.surface_text: Nor has it been shown how Art. 31 of the Constitution may be invoked to prevent cancellation of a contract in exercise of powers conferred by one of the terms of the contract itself.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No property deprivation under Art.31 when cancellation per contract clause

holdings.text: Article 16(1) confined to State employment/service, not supply contracts; petitioner is contractor, not employee.

anchor.surface_text: The main contention of the petitioner before us was thus under Art. 16 1 of the Constitution, and he claimed equal opportunity of employment under the State. To begin with, a contract for the supply of goods is not a contract of employment... Article 16 1 of the Constitution... is confined to employment by the State, and has reference to employment in service rather than as contractors... Art. 16 1 of the Constitution is not attracted to the facts.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Supply contract is sale of goods for price, not employment; Art.16(1) applies to servants/employees only

holdings.text: Petition under Article 32 wholly misconceived; no fundamental right involved in contract dispute; remedy in Civil Court.

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved. At best, it is a right to take the matter to the Civil Court, if so advised, and to claim damages for breach of contract, if any.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Dispute is mere breach of contract without fundamental rights infringement; Art.32 not for contractual remedies

anchor.surface_text: In our opinion, the petition under Art. 32 of the Constitution is wholly misconceived. No fundamental right is involved. At best, it is a right to take the matter to the Civil Court, if so advised, and to claim damages for breach of companytract,

outcome.relief_summary: Petition under Art. 32 held wholly misconceived; no fundamental right involved; remedy if any lies in civil court for breach of contract
